review.title: Edge-Linear First-Order Dependency Parsing with Undirected Minimum Spanning Tree Inference
review.abstract: The run time complexity of state-of-the-art inference algorithms in graph-based dependency parsing is super-linear in the number of input words (n). Recently, pruning algorithms for these models have shown to cut a large portion of the graph edges, with minimal damage to the resulting parse trees. Solving the inference problem in run time complexity determined solely by the number of edges (m) is hence of obvious importance.
histories: Accepted to ACL 2016, camera ready version

metadata.title: Edge-Linear First-Order Dependency Parsing with Undirected Minimum Spanning Tree Inference

sections.text: The runtime complexity of state-of-the-art inference algorithms in graph-based dependency parsing is superlinear in terms of the number of input words (s). Recently, it has been shown that pruning algorithms for these models cuts a large portion of the edges of the graphs, with minimal damage to the resulting parse trees. Therefore, solving the inference problem in runtime complexity, which is determined solely by the number of edges (m), is of obvious importance. We propose such an inference algorithm for first-order models, which encodes the problem as a minimal tree problem (MST) in an undirected graph. This allows us to use state-of-the-art undirected MST algorithms, whose runtime is expected and with a very high probability of O (m). A directed parse tree is then derived from the undirected MST problem and subsequently improved with respect to the directed parsing model, with both steps running in the first stage of the MST experiment.

sections.heading: 3 Undirected MST in Edge Linear Time
sections.text: There are two algorithms that solve the undirected MST problem in time practically linearly in the number of edges in the input graph. (These algorithms are based on substantially different approaches: one is deterministic and the other is randomized 6.6Both algorithms deal with a somewhat more general case in which the graph is not necessarily connected, in which case the minimal graph is calculated via forest (MSF). (In our case, in which the graph is connected, the MSF is reduced to an MST. The complexity of the first deterministic algorithm (Chazelle, 2000; Pettie and Ramachandran, 2002) isO (m · α (m, n)), in which the graph (m, n) is a natural inversion of the Ackermann function, whose value is lower than 5 for all practical values. Since this algorithm uses very complex data structures, we do not implement it in this paper.

sections.heading: 4 Undirected MST Inference for Dependency Parsing
sections.text: There are several challenges in constructing an undirected tree, while dependence on a steered parser requires a steered parser that applies only to a steered parser that applies an unregulated MST algorithm. (We refer to a steered MST parser that applies a steered MST algorithm to a steered MST algorithm.) The first problem is that a steered MST parser requires non-steered encoding. Unlike steered MST parsers that explicitly convert the steered nature of the dependency into a directed input graph to which a steered MST algorithm is applied (McDonald et al, 2005b), an undirected MST parser must be incorporated into an undirected direction information. In this section, we will consider two solutions to this problem. The second problem is that the output of an undirected MST algorithm is an undirected algorithm.

sections.heading: 5 Experiments and Results
sections.text: This year, it has reached the stage where it will be able to take the lead.

sections.heading: 6 Discussion
sections.text: We present a first-order graph-based dependency analysis model that runs in linear edge time with very high probability. In extensive multilingual experiments, our model behaves very similar to a standard firstorder parser. Furthermore, our results show the complementary nature of the models, with our model outperforming its direct counterpart by an average of 22.2% of the test sets. Beyond its practical implications, our work provides a novel intellectual contribution to demonstrating the power of undirected graph-based methods in solving an NLP problem that is directed in nature. We believe that this contribution has the potential to influence future research on additional NLP problems. The potential embodied in this work extends to a number of promising research directions: • Our algorithm can be used for efficient MST calculations in k-best trees.

Recent pruning algorithms for graph-based dependency parsing (Rush and Petrov, 2012; Riedel et al., 2012; Zhang and McDonald, 2012) have shown to cut a very large portion of the graph edges, with minimal damage to the resulting parse trees.

Recent pruning algorithms for graph-based dependency parsing (Rush and Petrov, 2012; Riedel et al., 2012; Zhang and McDonald, 2012) have shown to cut a very large portion of the graph edges, with minimal damage to the resulting parse trees. For example, Rush and Petrov (2012) demonstrated that a single O(n) pass of vinepruning (Eisner and Smith, 2005) can preserve > 98% of the correct edges, while ruling out > 86% of all possible edges.

metadata.abstractText: The run time complexity of state-of-theart inference algorithms in graph-based dependency parsing is super-linear in the number of input words (n). Recently, pruning algorithms for these models have shown to cut a large portion of the graph edges, with minimal damage to the resulting parse trees. Solving the inference problem in run time complexity determined solely by the number of edges (m) is hence of obvious importance. We propose such an inference algorithm for first-order models, which encodes the problem as a minimum spanning tree (MST) problem in an undirected graph. This allows us to utilize state-of-the-art undirected MST algorithms whose run time is O(m) at expectation and with a very high probability. A directed parse tree is then inferred from the undirected MST and is subsequently improved with respect to the directed parsing model through local greedy updates, both steps running inO(n) time. In experiments with 18 languages, a variant of the first-order MSTParser (McDonald et al., 2005b) that employs our algorithm performs very similarly to the original parser that runs an O(n2) directed MST inference.
